title: Lawrence F. Stengel
text:
Lawrence Francis Stengel (born August 7, 1952) is a former <a href="United%20States%20federal%20judge">United States District Judge</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20Eastern%20District%20of%20Pennsylvania">United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania</a>.
Education and career.
Born in <a href="Lancaster%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lancaster, Pennsylvania</a>, Stengel is the son of Lawrence E. Stengel (d. 2006), a lawyer. He received a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> degree from <a href="Saint%20Joseph%27s%20University">Saint Joseph's University</a> in 1974 and a <a href="Juris%20Doctor">Juris Doctor</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Pittsburgh%20School%20of%20Law">University of Pittsburgh School of Law</a> in 1980. He was a teacher at <a href="Lancaster%20Catholic%20High%20School">Lancaster Catholic High School</a> from 1974 to 1977. He was in private practice in <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> from 1980 to 1984, and in Lancaster from 1985 to 1990. He was a judge on the Lancaster County <a href="Pennsylvania%20courts%20of%20common%20pleas">Court of Common Pleas</a> from 1990 to 2004. He also teaches as an adjunct professor at <a href="Franklin%20%26amp%3B%20Marshall%20College">Franklin & Marshall College</a> from 1997 to present, and at <a href="Millersville%20University">Millersville University</a> from 2000 to 2004.
Notable case.
As a state judge, Stengel presided over the trial of Lisa Michelle Lambert for the <a href="murder%20of%20Laurie%20Show">murder of Laurie Show</a>, a noteworthy case in <a href="Lancaster%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lancaster County</a> history.
Federal judicial service.
On November 6, 2003, Stengel was nominated by President <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a> to a seat on the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20Eastern%20District%20of%20Pennsylvania">United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania</a> vacated by <a href="Ronald%20L.%20Buckwalter">Ronald L. Buckwalter</a>. Stengel was confirmed by the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> on June 16, 2004, and received his commission on June 21, 2004. Stengel became Chief Judge of the District on August 1, 2017, and resigned from that position on August 1, 2018. Stengel retired from active service on August 31, 2018, and joined the Saxton and Stump law firm to lead their investigations and mediation group, Optimal Dispute Resolutions.
Personal life.
Stengel has been married twice. He has five children. He lives in <a href="East%20Hempfield%20Township%2C%20Pennsylvania">East Hempfield Township, Pennsylvania</a>; as a federal judge, he commutes to work at the <a href="James%20A.%20Byrne%20United%20States%20Courthouse">James A. Byrne United States Courthouse</a> in Philadelphia.
